data.text:
Today’s artisans in Atuona excel in creating intricate works from wood and bone, continuing a rich tradition of craftsmanship. This charming village is also notable for being the place where two world-famous artists, Jacques Brel and Paul Gauguin, left their indelible marks.

What makes it so special

Why visit Hiva Oa?

The island that inspired Brel and Gauguin

Located northeast of Tahiti, Hiva Oa is one of the largest islands in the Marquesas archipelago. The village of Atuona, with its black sand bay, is the final resting place of two world-famous artists: painter Paul Gauguin and singer Jacques Brel.

Visitors can pay their respects at their graves, situated on the high ground above the village. Atuona also features a cultural center dedicated to Paul Gauguin and the Espace Jacques Brel museum, where you can see the small plane that once belonged to Brel.

In the Footsteps of Gauguin and Brel in Hiva Oa

A rich and vibrant culture

Brel and Gauguin’s names are forever associated with the island, but the true spirit of Hiva Oa lies in the valleys of Taaoa and Puamau. Opposite the village of Atuona, a mountain road winds to the valley of Puamau, home to the impressive archaeological site of Lipona.

This site is famed for its tiki, with the tallest standing at 2.57 meters. To the west of Atuona, the expansive archaeological site of Upeke is located in the valley of Taaoa, offering further insights into the island’s rich history and culture.

The Tiki of Taaoa and the Upeke Archeological Site

Not-to-be-missed

What to do in Hiva Oa?

Hiva Oa’s mountainous terrain offers several hiking trails that lead to magnificient scenic viewpoints. It’s best to explore the island with a guide, who can share the fascinating myths and legends associated with various sites. For a more relaxed day, head to Tahuata Island, just a few minutes by boat southeast of Hiva Oa. Unlike the motus of Bora Bora or Moorea, Tahuata boasts magnificent, deserted white sandy beaches that are equally stunning.

Suggested itinerary

Four days in Hiva Oa

Known as the Garden of the Marquesas Islands due to its lush vegetation, Hiva Oa features rugged mountains, steep cliffs, and a mix of black and white sand beaches. It’s a pilgrimage destination for admirers of the artist Paul Gauguin and the singer Jacques Brel, both of whom are buried in the local cemetery. The island also vaunts significant archaeological interest, with several tiki, paepae, and other remnants of its ancient civilisation. Discover these wonders on our suggested four-day itinerary for exploring Hiva Oa.

Where to stay in Hiva Oa?

When you visit Hiva Oa, you can stay in a hotel, a Tahitian Guesthouse, or aboard a chartered catamaran or cruise ship. No matter where you choose to spend your nights, you’re certain to have a dream holiday.

Getting here and getting around

You can fly to Hiva Oa with the domestic airline, but you’ll need to arrange transport from the airport with your accommodation in advance. For those who enjoy boat travel, the mixed cargo vessel Aranui 5 offers a unique journey, delivering both merchandise and passengers to the islands. There are also several sailboat charter companies that visit this island of myths and mystery. Once on the island, renting a car, preferably a four-wheel drive, is advisable for navigating Hiva Oa’s steep slopes. To reach some of the more remote valleys, a fishing boat or motorboat is often the best option. For a more leisurely exploration, consider hiring a horse.
